title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0001
text: Which package contains the Set interface?
explanation: The Set interface is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0002
text: Which of the following interfaces does Set extend?
explanation: The Set interface extends the Collection interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0003
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface?

options.text: Set does not allow duplicate elements

explanation: The Set interface does not allow duplicate elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0004
text: Which of the following classes implement the Set interface?
explanation: HashSet, LinkedHashSet, and TreeSet are implementations of the Set interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0005
text: Which of the following is true about HashSet?

options.text: HashSet does not maintain insertion order

explanation: HashSet does not maintain insertion order; it is based on hashing.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0006
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedHashSet?
explanation: LinkedHashSet maintains insertion order using a linked list internally.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0007
text: Which of the following is true about TreeSet?

options.text: TreeSet stores elements in sorted order

explanation: TreeSet stores elements in sorted order according to their natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0008
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and null elements?

options.text: LinkedHashSet does not allow null elements
All Set implementations allow multiple nulls

explanation: HashSet allows one null element, while TreeSet does not allow nulls.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0009
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and duplicates?

options.text: Set does not allow duplicate elements
Set allows duplicates only if sorted

explanation: The Set interface does not allow duplicate elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0010
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and ordering?
explanation: TreeSet maintains elements in sorted order, while HashSet and LinkedHashSet do not.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0011
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and synchronization?

options.text: Set is not synchronized by default

explanation: The Set interface is not synchronized by default; synchronization can be achieved using Collections.synchronizedSet().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0012
text: Which of the following methods can be used to synchronize a Set?
explanation: The Collections.synchronizedSet() method returns a synchronized (thread-safe) set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0013
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and immutability?

options.text: Sets can be made unmodifiable using Collections.unmodifiableSet()

explanation: Sets can be made unmodifiable using the Collections.unmodifiableSet() method.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0014
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and iteration?

options.text: Set provides an iterator() method for traversal

explanation: The iterator() method provides a way to traverse elements in a Set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and null elements in TreeSet?

options.text: TreeSet does not allow null elements

explanation: TreeSet does not allow null elements because it uses natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and duplicates in HashSet?

options.text: HashSet does not allow duplicate elements

explanation: HashSet does not allow duplicate elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and ordering in LinkedHashSet?
explanation: LinkedHashSet maintains insertion order using a linked list internally.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and performance?

options.text: HashSet provides constant-time performance for basic operations
All Set implementations have the same performance

explanation: HashSet provides constant-time performance for basic operations like add, remove, and contains.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and sorting?
explanation: TreeSet sorts elements automatically according to their natural order or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and equals()?

options.text: equals() compares sets based on elements only
equals() compares sets based on order
equals() compares sets based on references
equals() compares sets based on hash codes only

explanation: The equals() method compares sets based on their elements, not order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0021
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and hashCode()?

options.text: hashCode() is based on the elements in the set
hashCode() is based on insertion order
hashCode() is constant for all sets

explanation: The hashCode() method of a Set is based on the elements it contains, not their order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and duplicates in TreeSet?

options.text: TreeSet does not allow duplicate elements

explanation: TreeSet does not allow duplicate elements because it uses a sorted structure based on comparison.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and iteration order in HashSet?

options.text: HashSet does not maintain insertion order

explanation: HashSet does not maintain insertion order; it is based on hashing.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and fail-fast behavior?

options.text: Iterators of most Set implementations are fail-fast

explanation: Iterators of most Set implementations are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and null elements in HashSet?

options.text: HashSet does not allow null elements

explanation: HashSet allows one null element because it uses hashing and null has a fixed hash code.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and ordering in TreeSet?

options.text: TreeSet maintains elements in sorted order

explanation: TreeSet maintains elements in sorted order according to their natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and comparator?

options.text: TreeSet can use a custom Comparator for sorting

explanation: TreeSet can use a custom Comparator to define the sorting order of its elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and generics?
explanation: The Set interface is generic and can hold objects of any specified type.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and immutability in Java 9?
explanation: The Set.of() method introduced in Java 9 creates an immutable set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and null elements in Set.of()?

options.text: Set.of() does not allow null elements

explanation: The Set.of() method does not allow null elements and throws NullPointerException if null is passed.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and equals() comparison?

options.text: equals() compares sets based on elements only
equals() compares sets based on order
equals() compares sets based on references
equals() compares sets based on hash codes only

explanation: The equals() method compares sets based on their elements, not order.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and iteration order in LinkedHashSet?
explanation: LinkedHashSet maintains insertion order using a linked list internally.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and performance of TreeSet?

options.text: TreeSet provides O(log n) performance for basic operations

explanation: TreeSet provides O(log n) performance for basic operations like add, remove, and contains.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and fail-fast iterators?
explanation: Fail-fast iterators throw ConcurrentModificationException if the set is modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and thread safety?

options.text: Set is not thread-safe by default

explanation: The Set interface is not thread-safe by default; synchronization can be achieved using Collections.synchronizedSet().

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and iteration?

options.text: Set provides an iterator() method for traversal

explanation: The iterator() method provides a way to traverse elements in a Set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and duplicates in LinkedHashSet?

options.text: LinkedHashSet does not allow duplicate elements

explanation: LinkedHashSet does not allow duplicate elements, just like other Set implementations.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and ordering in HashSet?

options.text: HashSet does not maintain any order

explanation: HashSet does not maintain any order of elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and null elements in LinkedHashSet?

options.text: LinkedHashSet does not allow null elements

explanation: LinkedHashSet allows one null element, similar to HashSet.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and uniqueness?

options.text: Set ensures all elements are unique

explanation: The Set interface ensures that all elements are unique.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and add() method?

options.text: add() returns false if the element already exists
add() throws an exception if the element exists

explanation: The add() method returns false if the element already exists in the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and remove()?

options.text: remove() removes the specified element if present

explanation: The remove() method removes the specified element if it is present in the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and clear()?

options.text: clear() removes all elements from the set

explanation: The clear() method removes all elements from the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and contains()?

options.text: contains() checks if a specific element exists

explanation: The contains() method checks if a specific element exists in the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and size()?

options.text: size() returns the number of elements in the set
size() returns the capacity of the set

explanation: The size() method returns the number of elements in the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and isEmpty()?

options.text: isEmpty() returns true if the set has no elements
isEmpty() returns false if the set has no elements
isEmpty() throws an exception if empty
isEmpty() returns the size of the set

explanation: The isEmpty() method returns true if the set contains no elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and retainAll()?

options.text: retainAll() keeps only elements present in another collection

explanation: The retainAll() method retains only the elements that are also contained in another collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and removeAll()?

options.text: removeAll() removes all elements that are also in another collection

explanation: The removeAll() method removes all elements that are also contained in another collection.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about the Set interface and containsAll()?

options.text: containsAll() checks if all elements of another collection are present

explanation: The containsAll() method checks if all elements of another collection are present in the set.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkSet - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes the Set interface?

options.text: A collection that does not allow duplicate elements
A collection that allows duplicates and maintains order
A collection that stores elements in insertion order only

explanation: The Set interface represents a collection that does not allow duplicate elements.
